10027.description: Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. HEAF is seeking dedicated and passionate individuals to serve as academic coaches to provide tutoring and support to our College Quest (High School) students, grades 9-11. Our students need your help in the following subject areas High School: English, History (Global, U.S), Math (Trigonometry, Geometry, Algebra), Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, Spanish, French Time Commitment: 2hrs/Week Middle School: English Language Arts (ELA), Math (ratios, percentages, decimals, single variable equations, solving for X, plotting points on a graph) and Social Studies Time Commitment: 1/Hr a week, Saturdays About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our high school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s College Quest program operates on weekdays from 4:30-6:30pm. Academic Coaches are asked to make at least a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles General Requirements: Desire to work with and motivate high school students to achieve academic success Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring high school students Strong work ethic and professional values Strong interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: High School Academic Coach (Tutor)

10027.description: HEAF is seeking dedicated individuals to serve as academic coaches to providing tutoring and support and/or to serve as Teacher’s Assistants for our High Expectations (Middle School) students, grades 6-8. About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our middle school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s High Expectations tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-3:30pm after our Saturday Academy program. Academic Coaches are asked to make a minimum of a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Please note that additional hours and responsibilities may be available depending on the interests of the academic coach. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Teaching Assistant Position Summary HEAF seeks individuals who have a strong desire to work with middle school students to achieve academic success. As a classroom assistant, you will work alongside one of our teachers to provide supplemental support to our students. Teaching Assistants are asked to make a two hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Teaching Assistants will work alongside our teachers for our Saturday Academic Elective classes. Teacher’s Assistant Responsibilities: Assist with lunch supervision Create and maintain a positive classroom culture while using effective classroom management strategies Encourage positive student behavior that promotes character development Maintain meaningful positive rapport with parents and students General Requirements for both positions: Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: Middle School Academic Coach and Teaching Assistant - Harlem

10024.description: Digital Grandparents (DGI), We are seeking volunteers to assist older adults with improving their technology skills during our community service program. Volunteers are needed to engage in one -on-one tutoring with older adults on Saturdays from noon to 2 PM. The organization has had 501(c)(3) status since 2010. Send an email to info@dg-inc.org with the subject line \"I want to volunteer\" if you are interested in applying to become a DGI tutor or to learn more about our program.
10024.title: Volunteers - Assist Older Adults  with the Digital World

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Youth volunteers needed to play chess with older adults and brighten their day. Share a friendship across the chess board and gain community service hours. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Registration is still open on a rolling basis! Fall/Winter: Jan. 29 - May. 14 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: Volunteers at Star tutor students from low-income families who need help with reading, writing, math or other subjects. The students range in age from 2nd to 12th grade, and attend public and parochial schools across the city. About 65% of students come from families where Spanish is the primary language spoken at home. Tutors complete a written application form and interview, and are matched with an appropriate student. Once the tutor is matched, he/she receives an orientation, and then works one-to-one with the same student each week for two hours. The Center is open for tutoring on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3 to 7 pm, and on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 3:30 to 6 pm. You do not need to speak Spanish for this position. ***WE CURRENTLY HAVE A NUMBER OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO STILL DO NOT HAVE TUTORS! These students need primary help in Math and Science classes. The ability to help with other subjects, such as writing, would be helpful. You can apply now by visiting https://www.goddard.org/grcc/volunteer/starlearning/ and completing the Tutor Application: School Year.
10024.title: Math and Science Tutors Needed for HS Students!

10024.description: A special intergenerational reading adventure for 3rd and 4th graders. We are still accepting students on a rolling basis! Students spend time reading and discussing books with older adults. The program is ideal for youth to gain encouragement to reach for a book and spend time discussing books. students will nurture their natural love of reading and engage in a variety of fun and creative intergenerational activities. The group will read aloud a few books over the course of 14 sessions and discuss the major themes of the books respecting other’s differences and the value of kindness. Great food and art activities will follow. 2017 Dates: September 13 (orientation for youth,) September 27 October 4, 18, 25 November 1, 8, 15, 29 December 6, 13, 20 Jan 3, 10, 17 3rd and 4th graders can register online at: http://www.dorotusa.org/book. Only 12 spaces are available for youth. Parents need a pre-phone interview. For more information, please contact Shai Rosenfeld at srosenfeld@dorotusa.org or 917-441-5051
10024.title: Reading Adventure for 3rd and 4th Grade Students

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Spring 2017 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Spring 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 22 out of 27 scheduled sessions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10022.description: Change for Kids needs a skilled photographer to capture the experience at our annual Donor Appreciation Night on January 23, 2018. This is a special evening where we honor those individuals and organizations whose support propels us in our mission to bring an equal education to every child in NYC. There will be refreshments and a brief program. Please inquire for more details and have samples of your previous work ready for sharing.
10022.title: Photographer for Evening Event

10023.description: Volunteer opportunity - ACS Making Strides Against Breast Cancer/ Central Park Volunteers Needed! Are you looking to get more involved with your local community? Do you enjoy working with and meeting new people? Are you passionate about helping others and finishing the fight against cancer? If this sounds like you, the American Cancer Society needs you! The Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk of Central Park is one of the largest breast cancer awareness events in the nation. The money raised through the event helps save many lives by funding groundbreaking breast cancer research, providing free comprehensive information and support, and helping people take steps to reduce their risk of the disease or find it early when it’s most treatable. As the largest voluntary health organization in the country, we count on volunteers and volunteer driven organizations, agencies and companies to help make this event run smoothly and efficiently. The walk is on October 15th, 2017 located in Central Park and we need your help! Our volunteers help with important event details such as check in, water stations, information, and more. You’re there to help make the event truly special and to join, encourage, and support those in the fight against breast cancer! With just a few hours, you can help make a difference in countless lives and create a world with more birthdays! If interested, please contact our Event Manager Denise Solorzano, at Denise.Solorzano@cancer.org or by phone at 212-237-3813.
10023.title: Making Strides Against Breast Cancer-- Central Park Volunteer

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as of one New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. The Neighborhood House created our Legal Department in 2004 to address the lack of general civil legal organizations in our community. Our newly created monthly Tenants Advice Clinic allows community members to meet with an attorney or legal advocate to get help on housing related issues and landlord-tenant concerns. The volunteer will be responsible for the following: Greet clinic participants and assist them with initial paperwork; Work with supervisor to schedule individual interviews; Provide fact sheets and other information to clients; Conduct clerical duties, including photocopying and data entry; Volunteers should be able to communicate effectively with multiple visitors in a busy environment, have good organizational skills and basic computer literacy.
10021.title: Assistant for Legal Advocacy Tenants Advice Clinic

10031.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10031.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 192 Jacob H. Schiff, Manhattan)

10065.description: Thank you for your interest in volunteering with NYC Parks. Winter Jam is an annual event celebrating outdoor winter sports and recreation, to be held on Saturday, January 28, 2017 in Central Park. At Winter Jam we are looking for volunteers to help support the overall event: including but not limited to providing instruction and or oversight of event programming ( i.e. sledding, ice bowling) managing lines and crowds and fulfilling general event operations. In order to complete registration please fill out this form: https://goo.gl/forms/GubEzBVk1vCVRgfO2 If you have any questions, please contact Venus Melo at Venus.Melo@parks.nyc.gov with Winter Jam Volunteer in the subject line. Please note that at this time we are only accepting volunteers over the age of 18. https://www.nycgovparks.org/highlights/festivals/winter-jam
10065.title: Volunteer at Winter Jam, 1/27/18
10065.org: NYC Department of Parks and Recreation

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10014.title: Saturday Chinese Translators Needed!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity, or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of 2-4 students on the lesson, providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1st-8th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session (Session I: October-December, Session II: January-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - support instruction and engagement Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding students’ progress and/or concerns, and with the Senior Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience Time Commitment Session I: October-December 2017; 9 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Session II: January-April 2018; 14 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall 2017 Session I October 14, 21, 28 November 4, 11, 18 December 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring 2018 Session II January 6, 20, 27 February 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations Avenues: The World School (1st-5th Grade): 259 10th Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets Grace Church School (1st-5th Grade): 86 4th Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets Grace Church High School (6th-8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6th Street LREI (1st-5th Grade): 272 6th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s School (1st-3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson and Christopher Streets Brooklyn Location Berkeley Carroll (1st- 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6th and 7th Avenues Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners Ongoing professional development and training opportunities Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/High school transcript (for high school students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2. The online application form can also be found on our website at: http://goprojectnyc.org/get-involved/volunteer. If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org or call 212-533-3744 ATTN: Olivia Nunez, Senior Director of Community Engagement.

GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. 10014.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . 10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10280.description: WE NEED A SOUND DESIGNER BASED IN NEW YORK TO MIX A LOW BUDGET DOCUMENTARY-- A ONE HOUR BIOGRAPHICAL FILM WHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY MIXED BUT SINCE WE MADE SOME ADDITIONAL EDITING CHANGES, IT NOW NEEDS ANOTHER PASS.
10280.title: FILM SOUND DESIGNER

10019.description: It is difficult and sometimes impossible for seniors to travel by themselves to necessary appointments such as doctors and dentist appointments, and on necessary errands such as food shopping. The Senior Escort program makes these crucial trips possible. Encore’s Senior Escort Program is a volunteer program designed to give much needed assistance and support to aging members of our community. Otherwise, due to physical frailty and disability, vision or hearing impairment, and cognitive problems, our senior neighbors are forced to cancel their trips - which leads to rapid decline in health and quality of life. Things to know: As a volunteer, you will meet the senior at their front door, accompany them to their appointment or errand, and then accompany them back to their home. Trips typically take 1-3 hours, depending on the circumstance. You will travel via public transportation (each individual is responsible for their own metro card) or via cab (the senior participant is responsible for cab fees) The clients we serve live in Manhattan south of 110th Duties include: Helping the older person dress in outerwear such as coat, sweater or hat for the trip Helping the older person lock and unlock his/her residence Helping the older person with physical strains such as assistance on stairs and carrying/pushing the grocery cart Requirements: Commitment of at least 6 months Weekly commitments, preferred Successful criminal background check & reference check Flexible hours Monday-Friday and/or available at least one day a week Attend program orientation & training Must be at least 18 years old Sensitive and empathic with the senior population *Important* Schedule: The program is not a fixed schedule. Requests come in every week, at different times and days Monday-Friday. Volunteers must have flexibility during the work week, i.e. a part-time job, or flexible work hours. It is required that you have at least one entire day free from Monday-Friday, we will place the volunteer on an on-call basis depending on the requests that come in that week. Your role as a volunteer in this program is incredibly valuable and rewarding. Senior program participants are so grateful for your time and help. It is a simple but vital service.
10019.title: Taking Seniors To Doctors Appointments - A Much Needed Assistance. PLEASE - Make It Happen!

10019.description: We match isolated and lonely seniors with volunteers in the community who make weekly visits in the senior’s home. The Friendly Visiting program is an opportunity to form rewarding relationships and ongoing companionship for both seniors and volunteers. Seniors and their visitor can converse and enjoy the company, take part in activities like going to cafes and museums, share stories, learn new skills, and a variety of other things based on the desires of the companions. You will be matched with a senior who has a similar personality and interests and you can decide together how to spend your time. Visits can easily fit into your schedule because matches are made based on your availability. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months or 1 year. Your time as a friendly visitor is invaluable, and you gain a new friend!
10019.title: Provide Companionship To Homebound & Isolated Senior - It is Only One Hour Per Week!!!

10018.description: Every Monday we offer free winter clothing to people in the Hell's Kitchen community. As the weather gets colder, the need for warm clothes increases. We utilize volunteers as shoppers to help individuals from the community find the clothes they need in our clothing closet. This is a great way to serve the community in a direct way. Mondays 12:30 pm to 3:00 pm
10018.title: Winter Clothing Closet

10018.description: Global Green NY is looking for volunteers to help with our food donation work this summer. Volunteer opportunities are for food donation pick-ups in Midtown Manhattan on weekday nights (during typical resutrant closing time), where food will then be transported to food banks and shelters for those in need. http://www.globalgreen.org/getinvolved/ Ideally volunteers: For food rescue volunteers, the only qualifications are that they are punctual, reliable and able to carry 20+ lbs of food.
10018.title: New York GGUSA Volunteer

10018.description: The Step Up program is a six month goal focused mentoring/ coaching program fro high school students. The goal of the program is to enhance self-confidence and self- esteem which then leads to positive change in the lives of the students. In order to be a mentor you must be 24 or older. For further information please contact Alexandria at Alex@nyunlockingfutures.org / 212-791-4927 ext #263.
10018.title: Male or Female Mentors for our "Step Up" program!

10018.description: America Needs You fights for economic mobility for ambitious, first generation college students. We do this by providing transformative mentorship and intensive career development. Our flagship Fellows Program is a two-year, intensive mentoring and professional training program where first-generation students (\"Fellows\") are paired with young professional volunteers. Our New York program workshops take place in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Career Coaches work with college students during Saturday sessions to build their professional skills and help them realize their career potential. ANY curriculum covers all kinds of professional development topics from resume preparation and interview etiquette to giving and receiving feedback and managing up. At workshops, Career Coaches typically participate in group or one-on-one work with Fellows; for example, writing and reviewing a cover letter or building a pros/cons list for deciding between two internships. Please complete the survey below to be contacted about volunteering at an upcoming workshop: https://newyorkneedsyou.wufoo.com/forms/rn5685a0sqkdux/
10018.title: Volunteer to mentor ambitious first-generation college students!

10038.description: Reach the World is a New York City-based nonprofit organization that makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident and compassionate global citizens. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The guest count is typically between 150 and 200 guests from diverse New York City and Connecticut-based industries. The event format includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree- stay tuned for the big reveal! The success of Reach the World's events are entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make each event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. Reach the World welcomes all serious applicants to the 2018 Benefit Committee. The 2018 Benefit will take place on April 4 th, 2018 at the Boathouse in Central Park. To apply and for more information, please fill out this online application: https://www.tfaforms.com/4651651
10038.title: Join Reach the World's 2018 Annual Benefit Committee

10038.description: Do you have a passion for global education and international exchange? Do you believe in grassroots programs that leverage volunteer energies for a social good? Are you excited by events and production? Reach the World is seeking a mature volunteer looking to advance his/her networking, fundraising and event management skills for a 'team lead’ position of Reach the World’s 2018 Benefit Committee. This volunteer position (4-10h/week) reports to RTW's Development Manager. This position has a flexible start date between December 1, 2017 and January 2, 2018 and runs until the gala on April 6th 2018. The position is unpaid. The volunteer who secures the most donations receives two tickets to the event and is entered into the raffle! Responsibilities: Event Planning: Participate in bi-weekly evening meetings; lead the strategy for securing fashion prize donations for the silent auction; manage other volunteers Fashion Industry Outreach and Donor Management: Reach out to donors in person, through email and over the phone to secure a minimum of 25 fashion prizes for the silent auction (women’s, men’s, kids, home, office); leverage network to increase donations; manage relationships with donors in the fashion industry Gala Volunteering: Volunteer at the event (unless you plan to purchase a ticket and attend) Qualifications: Organized self-starter Fearless communicator Works well under pressure Team player Experience planning events and/or volunteering with a nonprofit is a bonus About Reach the World and the 2018 Annual Benefit Dinner Reach the World makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident global citizens. Enabled by our virtual exchange platform, classrooms and volunteer travelers explore the world together. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The event includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree - stay tuned! The success of Reach the World's event is entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make the event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. How to Apply Please submit a cover letter and resume by email to brianna@reachtheworld.org. No phone, email, mail, or fax inquiries will receive a response. Thank you for your interest in joining Reach the World on its exciting journey!
10038.title: Fashion Prize Manager

10038.description: American Youth Table Tennis seeks interested college students in the New York City Metro Area to teach high school students the sport of table tennis, leadership, fair play, respect and teamwork. Table Tennis expertise required. As a volunteer coach you will receive a small per visit stipend per visit to cover transportation costs and effort. We will assign you to a New York City High School Table Tennis Program as an Assistant Table Tennis Coach. Duties will include, teaching basic and intermediate table tennis - footwork, serve, serve return, backhand, forehand, tactics, loop, loop drive as well as serving multi-ball and providing a positive and exciting framework for play, and dialog. American Youth Table Tennis and New York City Department of Education have teamed up to make this opportunity available to you. Table Tennis is an official varsity sport in New York City. We will be accepting applications in November and through to the end of January. We are in need of expert collegiate table tennis players to assist in selected High School Programs for the 2017-18 season which begins in December and Continues through March 2018 As an Assistant Coach, you will be giving back to the New York City community by imparting your table tennis knowledge on receptive and interested high school students. This program will look good on your resume and will help the next generation of collegiate table tennis players.
10038.title: Youth Table Tennis Coach - Collegiate Internship Program

10038.description: Mentor a 13-18 year old student to provide guidance and broaden his or her horizons. Help a student grow to be confident, caring young adult by becoming a role model and someone he or she can rely on. Mentors and mentees are matched after carefully considering the goals of the mentee and what the mentor can do to support that goal. We are currently looking for more male mentors. The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.
10038.title: Middle School/High School Mentor (male)

10038.description: Teach 4th and 5th graders the fundamentals of basketball and what teamwork really is. Coach the students and help them win games against other schools by guiding them through the seasons. Be the one to show the young students the love for the game.
10038.title: Volunteer Basketball Coaches Needed

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10038.description: We are looking for volunteers with dance experience to help run a weekly movement-based creative workshop for students with intellectual disabilities in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, Wednesdays from 11-12. This opportunity takes place over 12 weeks, for a small group of middle and high school students. The workshop will culminate with an informal showing. We are also looking for volunteer yoga instructors in all boroughs.
10038.title: Looking for Dance Teachers and Yoga Instructors

10013.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Senior Center at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue is a vibrant program that provides hundreds of older adults with educational, cultural, health and social activities every week. We are seeking instructors for a variety of classes and activities including: Zumba Chair Yoga Mah Jong Line Dancing Conversational Italian Book Discussion Group Digital Photography Instructors lead their respective classes/activities once per week on weekdays. If you have one of the skills above and are interested in sharing your time and knowledge with active and enthusiastic older adults please contact Anthony Snowden, Volunteer Director at asnowden@lenoxhill.org or 212-218-0487.
10013.title: Instructor for Senior Center

10011.description: Do you have a passion for dance? Do you enjoy working with children? Are you looking to gain experience and new skills? then volunteering with Dance to Unite, Inc. could be the right volunteer opportunity for you! Dance to Unite, Inc. is a non-profit organization whose mission is to use dance as a vehicle to teach and to celebrate cultural diversity. WE ARE LOOKING FOR VOLUNTEER DANCE TEACHERS AND TEACHER ASSISTANTS! Qualified applicants are required to have some background in dance but most imporatntly a strong interest and desire to work with inner city children and youth. A one hour weekly comittment is required throughout the school year (October-June) and availability during after-school hours (3:00-6:00pm). We offer FREE training in a warm and supportive environment with plently of opportunities for professional and personal growth. Responsibilities of Volunteer Dance Teachers: -Become familiar and comfortable with implementing our educational component which includes leading our 5-10 minutes 'Circle Talk' . *We provide supervision, guidance and support to ensure that everyone is properly trained and fully prepared to implement our educational component. -Create and teach a year-round dance routine and choose the music that will accompany your choreography. -Facilitate one special guest artist workshop (which is offered to each Dance to Unite, Inc. Class throught the school year) by briefing students about the style of dance or other artistic medium which is explored that day and collaborate with all those involved in making the workshop a success. Responsibilities of Dance Teacher Assistants: -Work closely with a teacher and support her/his efforts in fulfilling all of her/his duties/responsibilities. -Participate in/or lead a weekly warm-up exercise routine. -Learn the choreography taught by the teacher by rehearsing a weekly dance routine with the students. -Assist the teacher with running/managing the classroom by providing positive feedback and addressing inappropriate behaviors when needed. -Periodically take photos/videos that can be used for our social media (using a camera phone). Benefits of these volunteer opportunities: -Gain knowledge/experience and develop various set of skills related to creating a year-round dance choreography, leading a short discussion and managing a classroom. -Receive references and recommendation letters as evidence to support your accomplishments when applying for internships, jobs or graduate schools. *Internship opportunities are available to both high school and college students. -Recieve free training in a warm and supportive environment that offers countless opportunities for professional and personal growth. -Volunteers who have been with us long enough to show commitment and dedication to our organization are acknowledged by being featured on our organization's website. -Cultivate new personal and professional contacts. -Receive a free invitation to our annual benefit and other events. -Join our Dance to Unite, Inc. Meetup group and meet like-minded people in the local community who share a passion for making a difference. THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN JOINING OUR DANCE TO UNITE FAMILY! For further information, please check our website: www.dancetounite.org FOR QUESTIONS AND INQUIRIES, PLEASE CONTACT: info@dancetounite.org
10011.title: Teach dance to inner city kids!

10011.description: GRANT WRITER The Grant Writer is primarily responsible for developing and writing grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, and will persuasively communicate CSP's mission and programs to potential funders. Reporting to the Executive Director, the Grant Writer will assemble and submit grant requests, establish and maintain personal contact and relationships with foundation contacts, conduct prospect research, and maintain a calendar of submissions and other deadlines. To get a response please send RESUME.
10011.title: Grant Writer

10011.description: Computer/It - Tech Support - All aspects of tech support for the organization including maintenance, troubleshoot, specially ANTI-VIRUS, and optimal functioning of the system. Must have experience with Microsoft and Windows systems. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Computer support

10011.description: Education Program Coordinator - Chelsea Sculpture Park. New York , New York. Basic Requirements: BA or MA in related discipline required (Art Education) Post college professional work experience required Demonstrated experience with art education or other informal art programming and curriculum design Demonstrated knowledge of Microsoft computer programs and excellent presentation skills Job Responsibilities: Coordinate and develop of new partner-institution/organization relationships and curriculum Provide leadership and direction towards the design and implementation of art educational programming and curriculum in compliance with national and state learning objectives, accreditation guidelines, and innovative art methodologies Establish and grow professional relationships with constituents, peers, associations and partner schools To Apply: Please submit your resume with cover letter and references to the contact information listed below. Set against the backdrop of the Hudson River, Chelsea Sculpture Park will offer fine art for the public to experience, up close and outdoors. The park's mission is to provide an aesthetic oasis in the Chelsea Cove section of Hudson River Park located between 22nd and 26th Streets, just steps away from the world-class Chelsea Art District. We are looking for a Education Program Coordinator to assist the founder and executive-director of Chelsea Sculpture Park develop and implement an educational program foccusing on the exhibitions of the sculpture park.
10011.title: Educational Program - Coordinator

10011.description: Chelsea Sculpture Park New York, New York Are you considering a future in arts administration, nonprofit management, fundraising, arts education or a related field? This is a great opportunity to gain experience working at a brand new nonprofit arts organization that is dedicated to building a sculpture park on the banks of the Hudson River Park. Gain invaluable insights and learn fundraising strategies as part of a dynamic Development team. Assist with prospect research, special events, direct mail, and our donor database, as well as pursue special projects. Internship credit may be arranged through your academic program. The ideal candidate will be organized and detail-oriented, and have good computer skills. Those with prospect research experience and graduate students in arts administration and arts education are especially welcome. The hours for this position are flexible within the work week. A modest stipend is available. To Apply: Please be sure to include current contact information so that we may arrange an interview. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Development Intern

10036.description: LiveOn NY is hosting their 28th Annual Conference on Aging & Vendor Expo! Leaders and professionals in the aging field will come together at this event to network, share innovative ideas and more! We are in need of volunteers to help us stuff and pack bags for the attendees. Days needed: Thursday, January 18 & Friday, January 19 If you are available on both days, reach out the Victoria! vthornton@liveon-ny.org 212-398-6565 ext 235
10036.title: Bag Stuffing for Annual Conference!

10036.description: We are in need of a creative movement, beginner modern dance teacher for our Wednesday's youth arts program! Teaching ages 4-6yrs old from 4:00-4:45pm. Love of dance, movement, children, and teaching is a must! Come dance with us!
10036.title: Children's Creative Movement Teacher for Salvation Army

10036.description: In need of a hip hop dance teacher, to instruct our Wednesday night youth programs! Class is from 6-6:45pm, and ages range from 6-12yrs old. Takes place in our Times Square building, in a large beautiful studio with new wooden floors, barres, and mirrors. Love of dance, teaching, and working with kids is a must! Come dance with us!
10036.title: Children's hip hop teacher needed at Salvation Army!

10036.description: The Salvation Army of Times Square is in need of two ballet teachers to instruct our 6-13yr olds. Basic beginner level ballet technique, love of children, and passion for teaching is a must! Starting in Jan. of 2018! We have a beautiful large dance studio with new wooden floors, barres, and mirrors. Come dance with our cute kiddos!
10036.title: Childrens' Ballet Teacher needed at the Salvation Army!

10036.description: Theater 315 of the Salvation Army at Times Square, is in need of a Drama teacher for their 2018 semester. You would be teaching acting to a group of about 10 young artists, ages 8-12yrs old, each Wednesday from 6-6:45pm.
10036.title: Children's Drama Teacher Needed!

10017.description: ALSAC is the fundraising and awareness organization for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. We are looking for passionate and driven volunteers who are ready to make a difference for St. Jude. We are recruiting volunteers to help for few hours Monday-Friday with office related work during the holiday season. Please contact Fatima Hameed for more information! Fatima Hameed Admin Volunteer Coordinator ALSAC, the fundraising and awareness organization for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital(r) 220 E 42 nd St, Suite 435, New York, NY 10017 Office: 212-379-1600 Email: Fatima.hameed@stjude.org
10017.title: ALSAC-St. Jude in Office Volunteering

10017.description: The Event Chair serves as the lead volunteer for implementation of the St. Jude Walk/Run to End Childhood Cancer in their community. The Event Chair engages community members to serve in subcommittee roles while developing and implementing a successful annual community event to raise funds and awareness of St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. A successful Event Chair possesses strong organization, leadership and communication skills. This individual is able to commit approximately 10-15 hours a month to St. Jude Walk/Run efforts.
10017.title: St. Jude Walk/Run to End Childhood Cancer - Event Chair (Jersey Shore, NJ)

10016.title: Be A Friend Day
10016.org: Helping Hands for the Disabled of NYC

10016.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.
10016.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10016.description: READING BUDDY PLUS connects a younger child with the same adult volunteer every other Tuesday from October- June. Every time they visit the Reading Center, children share a story one-on-one with the same buddy. This continuity offers a child the same opportunity to improve their reading skills and open up their imagination, but more importantly it gives them the chance to deepen the bonds and their sense of trust with one person. As their friendships with the children evolve, volunteers can better help the children in this program to see their world in a more positive light. And, in talking about the stories they share, the children can learn to use their imaginations to make a difference in their own lives. http://pajamaprogram.org/ Requirements and Commitments: ALL volunteers must pass a background check and fill out a volunteer application to be able to participate in Reading Buddy Plus. All personal information will be kept confidential. This program runs every other Tuesday from 12 P.M. - 1 P.M. from October- June. Volunteers MUST commit to the ENTIRE school year. If interested, please email Chrissie Martinez at chrissie@pajamaprogram.org to receive further information.
10016.title: Share the Joy of Reading with a Child

10016.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10016.title: Deliver Food
10016.org: Helping Hands for the Disabled of NYC

10033.description: Food pantry volunteers needed in Washington Heights. The pantry is open Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. Volunteers may come for one, two, or three days! This client choice food pantry serves New Yorkers in vulnerable situations, many of which are older adults. Volunteers will assist clients in choosing food items and help keep the pantry stocked for food recipients. Volunteers must be comfortable with light to moderate lifting and movement, for example, bending over to stock the food pantry shelves with cans, or filling a grocery bag with shelf-stable items when assisting food recipients. Familiarity of the Spanish language a plus, but not required.
10033.title: Volunteer in a Washington Heights Food Pantry

10032.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book, a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a writing, research or art coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work in the classroom. This classroom workshop needs your help in Washington Heights. To volunteer, reply with the program code and date to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 44AK-T Date: Wednesday, January 3rd, 2018 Time: 8:45 - 10:15 AM Volunteer Role: Writing Coach About the workshop: Fourth-graders read Francisco’s Kites by Alicia Klepeis, a bilingual picture book that tells the story of a boy who makes beautiful kites from found objects. Students will develop a business plan for a community-based, environmentally friendly product or service, then write descriptions of their product or service that explain its value. Writing coaches will guide them in producing drafts of their plans, incorporating their research and content-specific vocabulary. For dates of other workshops around New York City, please visit our volunteer opportunities page. To join our team and receive announcements of new classroom programs and other opportunities as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10032.title: Writing coach for Washington Hts, NYC public school literacy program (44akt)

10032.description: New York Common Pantry is looking for volunteers to help with our program Nourish, which works to help improve the health of low income seniors by supplementing their diet with nutritious USDA food. Volunteers for this project will help assemble and distribute groceries based on a set menu at Mary Mcleod Senior Center. We distribute groceries every 1st Monday and 1st Tuesday of the month at this site.
10032.title: Help Seniors Receive Free Groceries at Mary Mcleod Senior Center

Burg's Unbound, a novel-in-verse about a girl who escapes a Virginia plantation with her family to seek refuge in the Dismal Swamp, a remote wilderness where a community of slaves hid. Students will use their reading, as well as research from other resources, to write opinion pieces that debate the decision to escape from slavery.
